channel.title: Writing Tips | Alliance SciComm & Consulting, LLC

item.title: The 'Jigsaw' Method for Scientific Writing
item.description:

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 [type="submit"]::-moz-focus-inner {

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 input[type="checkbox"] {

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 input[type="date"],

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 textarea {

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 [type="number"]::-webkit-inner-spin-button,
  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 [type="number"]::-webkit-outer-spin-button {

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 [type="search"] {

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 [type="search"]::-webkit-search-cancel-button,

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 ::-webkit-file-upload-button {

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 [hidden] {

  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-modal {
    top: 0;
    left: 0;
    right: 0;
    bottom: 0;
    display: block;
    opacity: 0;
    outline: 0;
    z-index: -1;
    position: fixed;
    background: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.4);
    overflow-x: hidden;
    overflow-y: auto;
    -webkit-transition: opacity 0.4s, visibility 0.4s;
    transition: opacity 0.4s, visibility 0.4s;
    visibility: hidden;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-modal.fd-is-open {
    opacity: 1;
    z-index: 1040;
    visibility: visible;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-modal__dialog {
    width: -webkit-calc(100% - 60px);
    width: calc(100% - 60px);
    margin: 30px auto;
    display: -webkit-box;
    display: flex;
    position: relative;
    max-width: 750px;
    min-height: -webkit-calc(100% - 60px);
    min-height: calc(100% - 60px);
    -webkit-box-align: center;
    align-items: center;
    pointer-events: none;
    -webkit-box-pack: center;
    justify-content: center;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-modal__content {
    width: 100%;
    border: 0 solid #d7d7d7;
    display: -webkit-box;
    display: flex;
    outline: 0;
    position: relative;
    background: #fff;
    box-shadow: 6.5px 11.3px 19px 0 rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.11);
    border-radius: 0;
    -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
    -webkit-box-direction: normal;
    flex-direction: column;
    pointer-events: auto;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-modal__body {
    -webkit-box-flex: 1;
    flex: 1 1 auto;
    padding: 0;
    position: relative;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-modal__close {
    top: 0;
    color: #000;
    right: 0;
    width: 40px;
    border: 0;
    cursor: pointer;
    height: 40px;
    margin: 0;
    display: -webkit-box;
    display: flex;
    padding: 0;
    z-index: 9999;
    position: absolute;
    background: transparent;
    -webkit-box-align: center;
    align-items: center;
    line-height: 1;
    -webkit-box-pack: center;
    justify-content: center;
    -webkit-appearance: none;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-modal__close svg {
    color: inherit;
    width: 10px;
    height: auto;
    display: block;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-modal__close:hover,
  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-modal__close:focus,
  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-modal__close:active {

  }

  @media (max-width: 575px) {

      width: -webkit-calc(100% - 30px);
      width: calc(100% - 30px);
      margin: 15px auto;
      min-height: -webkit-calc(100% - 30px);
      min-height: calc(100% - 30px);
    }
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-control {
    width: 100%;
    display: block;
    outline: none;
    position: relative;
    -webkit-appearance: none;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-control:focus {
    outline: none;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-control::-webkit-input-placeholder {
    color: transparent !important;
    opacity: 0 !important;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-control::-moz-placeholder {

    opacity: 0 !important;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-control:-ms-input-placeholder {
    color: transparent !important;
    opacity: 0 !important;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-control::placeholder {
    color: transparent !important;
    opacity: 0 !important;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-label {
    top: 0;
    left: 0;
    right: 0;
    margin: 0;
    overflow: hidden;
    position: absolute;
    white-space: nowrap;
    text-overflow: ellipsis;
    pointer-events: none;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-control:not(:-moz-placeholder-shown)+.fd-form-label {
    opacity: 0;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-control:not(:-ms-input-placeholder)+.fd-form-label {
    opacity: 0;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-control:not(:placeholder-shown)+.fd-form-label {
    opacity: 0;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-description {
    margin: 5px 0 0 0;
    font-size: 0.8em;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-feedback {
    margin: 5px 0 0 0;
    font-size: 0.8em;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-group {
    margin: 0 0 15px;
    position: relative;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-group.fd-has-success .fd-form-feedback,
  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-group.fd-has-success .fd-form-check {
    color: #02dba8 !important;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-group.fd-has-success .fd-form-control {
    color: #02dba8 !important;
    border-color: #02dba8 !important;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-group.fd-has-success .fd-form-feedback {
    display: block;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-group.fd-has-error .fd-form-feedback,
  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-group.fd-has-error .fd-form-check {
    color: #eb3d3b !important;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-group.fd-has-error .fd-form-control {
    color: #eb3d3b !important;
    border-color: #eb3d3b !important;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-group.fd-has-error .fd-form-feedback {
    display: block;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-btn {
    cursor: pointer;
    display: -webkit-inline-box;
    display: inline-flex;
    outline: none;
    max-width: 100%;
    font-style: normal;
    text-align: center;
    -webkit-box-align: center;
    align-items: center;
    text-shadow: none;
    white-space: normal;
    -webkit-box-pack: center;
    justify-content: center;
    text-decoration: none;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-btn:hover {
    outline: none;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-btn:focus {
    outline: none;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-btn:disabled {
    opacity: 0.8;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-check {
    cursor: pointer;
    margin: 0;
    display: -webkit-box;
    display: flex;
    position: relative;
    -webkit-box-align: center;
    align-items: center;
    padding-left: 30px;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-check__input {
    top: 0;
    left: 0;
    width: 18px;
    height: 18px;
    opacity: 0;
    z-index: -1;
    position: absolute;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-check__checkmark {
    top: 0;
    left: 0;
    width: 18px;
    border: 1px solid #c4c4c4;
    height: 18px;
    display: block;
    position: absolute;
    background: #ffffff;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-check__label {
    margin: 0;
    font-size: 14px;
    text-align: left;
    word-break: break-word;
    font-weight: 400;
    line-height: 18px;
    letter-spacing: 0.01em;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-check__input:checked+.fd-form-check__checkmark::after {
    opacity: 1;
    z-index: 1;
    visibility: visible;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-check__checkmark::after {
    top: -1px;
    left: -1px;
    width: 18px;
    height: 18px;
    content: "";
    display: block;
    opacity: 0;
    z-index: -1;
    position: absolute;
    -webkit-transition: opacity 0.4s, z-index 0.4s;
    transition: opacity 0.4s, z-index 0.4s;
    visibility: inherit;
    background-size: 12px;
    background-image: url("data:image/svg+xml,%3csvg xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg' fill='black' width='12' height='10' viewBox='0 0 11.51 8.2'%3e%3ctitle%3echeck%3c/title%3e%3cpath d='M4.05%2c8.2A.74.74%2c0%2c0%2c1%2c3.52%2c8L.22%2c4.68A.75.75%2c0%2c0%2c1%2c1.28%2c3.62l3.3%2c3.3A.75.75%2c0%2c0%2c1%2c4.58%2c8%2c.74.74%2c0%2c0%2c1%2c4.05%2c8.2Z'/%3e%3cpath d='M4.06%2c8.2A.74.74%2c0%2c0%2c1%2c3.53%2c8a.75.75%2c0%2c0%2c1%2c0-1.06l6.7-6.7a.75.75%2c0%2c0%2c1%2c1.06%2c1.06L4.59%2c8A.74.74%2c0%2c0%2c1%2c4.06%2c8.2Z'/%3e%3c/svg%3e");
    background-repeat: no-repeat;
    background-position: center center;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-check__input:focus {
    outline: none;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-content {
    position: relative;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-has-success .fd-form-content {
    display: none;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-has-captcha .fd-form-content>*:not(.fd-form-captcha) {
    opacity: 0;
    visibility: hidden;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-captcha {
    top: 0;
    left: 0;
    width: 100%;
    height: 100%;
    display: -webkit-box;
    display: flex;
    position: absolute;
    -webkit-box-align: center;
    align-items: center;
    -webkit-box-pack: start;
    justify-content: flex-start;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-success {
    display: none;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-has-success .fd-form-success {
    display: block;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-success>*:last-child {
    margin-bottom: 0;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-error {
    display: none;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-has-error .fd-form-error {
    display: block;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-error>*:last-child {
    margin-bottom: 0;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-focus-visible,
  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-check__input.fd-focus-visible+.fd-form-check__checkmark {
    outline: none;
    box-shadow: 0 0 0 2px #fff, 0 0 0 6px #000 !important;
    -webkit-transition: box-shadow 0.2s !important;
    transition: box-shadow 0.2s !important;
  }

  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-focus-visible,
  [data-ff-el="root"].ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4 .fd-form-check__input.fd-focus-visible+.fd-form-check__checkmark {

<p>Is there a right way to put a puzzle together? What about drafting a paper?</p>
<p>Writing a paper or article is much like putting a jigsaw puzzle together, both are composed of many smaller pieces. And like a puzzle, it doesn’t matter how or where you start. What matters is that it gets done.</p>
<p>The jigsaw writing method is an approach to writing that encourages you to break the manuscript down into smaller sections or topics and start where you feel inspired</p>
<h2 id="how-does-the-jigsaw-method-work">How does the jigsaw method work?</h2>
<ol>
<li>
<p>After you’ve created an outline for your manuscript, pick a section or topic of the outline to begin drafting.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Write until you finish the section, your writing session, or run out of things to say.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Review the outline and pick another place to begin writing.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Rinse and repeat until your writing session is over and/or you’ve completed your first draft.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<h2 id="when-should-i-use-the-jigsaw-method-for-drafting">When should I use the jigsaw method for drafting?</h2>
<p>Whenever you feel inspired!</p>
<p>Perhaps you’ve been mulling over the implications or limitations of your research. If so, it makes more sense to draft the relevant portion of the discussion instead of forcing yourself to start at the beginning or even where you left off last time.</p>
<p>While the introduction is the first section of the outline, you don’t have to write it first. Drafting the methods or results is often a great place to get your brain working on a new manuscript.</p>
<p>Importantly, the jigsaw method is fractal. That is, it scales to different levels of writing, from the introduction to the concluding paragraph of the introduction; wherever it is, start where you feel inspired.</p>
<h2 id="what-about-continuity-and-flow">What about continuity and flow?</h2>
<p>Incorporating the jigsaw puzzle method into your writing process can prevent writer’s block that stems from restrictive approaches to drafting a manuscript. But can it affect the overall flow of the manuscript?</p>
<p>It’s possible that starting at different places in the manuscript at different times could make the flow disjointed. But that can also happen even if you write from start to finish because you may choose to change the order or logic during the revision process.</p>
<p>Furthermore, it’s often easier to revise and rework the words that you have on the page than to get the words down in the first place. My suggestion is to get the words first and focus on the flow later.</p>
<h2 id="resources">Resources</h2>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://lithub.com/7-methods-for-writing-your-first-draft/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">7 Methods for Writing Your First Draft</a></li>
</ul>
<hr>
<p><strong>The <a href="https://alliancescc.github.io/post/draft_methods_intro/">introduction and full list</a> of methods for writing the first manuscript draft.</strong></p>

item.title: The 'Incubation' Method for Scientific Writing
item.description:

    sm.src = h + s + '.mjs' + v;

    sn.async = true;

  window.fd('form:handle', {
    formId: '[61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4]',
    rootEl: '.ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4',
  });

<blockquote>
<p>“Although I have been advocating getting pen to paper as early as possible, there are writers who let an idea remain in their heads for a long time. They will ruminate at length, letting the subconscious stay constantly engaged with the subject so that characters, plot and atmosphere form without any forced deliberation… The trick, I suppose, is knowing when to stop dreaming and get down to it.” - Ross Raisin</p>
</blockquote>
<p>For many people there’s a period of time after researching and outlining a topic and before sitting down to write about it during which they simply think about it. Long or short, this invisible and intangible act is a perfectly valid part of the drafting process known as incubation or percolation time.</p>
<h2 id="how-does-the-incubation-method-work">How does the incubation method work?</h2>
<p>How or when it works varies for each individual. Authors who use it will take time before any drafting begins to process and integrate their research into a coherent message.</p>
<p>Some will draft an entire article or essay at a time. Others may compile smaller pieces like paragraphs or sentences between writing bouts.</p>
<p>The key to this method is finding time to actively think about your writing project without trying to also put words on the page.</p>
<p>To avoid the guilt of “doing nothing”, consider using repetitive tasks like washing dishes, walking, and driving to facilitate mind wandering and rumination on your topic without feeling unproductive. Be sure to keep a notepad or voice recorder nearby to collect any good thoughts! Then you can review them when it’s time to put pen to page.</p>
<h2 id="when-should-i-use-the-incubation-method">When should I use the incubation method?</h2>
<p>If you have a writing project that feels disconnected, disjointed, or otherwise unclear when you sit to work on it then you might benefit from some time away from your project. A week or even a couple of days can often provide the space necessary for your brain to process the material and find solutions.</p>
<h2 id="what-about-deadlines">What about deadlines?</h2>
<p>In many cases, your project will have a deadline. Sometimes days but usually weeks or months away. Working backward from the deadline, create a timetable to identify when the first draft needs to be completed, and work in at least one week between ending your main research phase and beginning the drafting phase. That should be enough incubation time to mentally assimilate and organize your research. For shorter projects and deadlines, you may only need (or have available) a day or two.</p>
<h2 id="resources">Resources</h2>
<ul>
<li>
<p><a href="https://lithub.com/7-methods-for-writing-your-first-draft/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">7 Methods for Writing Your First Draft</a></p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="https://devonellington.substack.com/p/percolation-time" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Percolation Time</a></p>
</li>
</ul>
<hr>
<p><strong>The <a href="https://alliancescc.github.io/post/draft_methods_intro/">introduction and full list</a> of methods for writing the first manuscript draft.</strong></p>

item.title: The ‘Set Up’ Method for Scientific Writing

    var sm = d.createElement(t);
    sm.async = true;
    sm.type = 'module';
    sm.src = h + s + '.mjs' + v;
    f.parentNode.insertBefore(sm, f);
    var sn = d.createElement(t);
    sn.async = true;

    formId: '[61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4]',

  });

<blockquote>
<p>“The best way is always to stop when you are going good and when you know what will happen next.” By-Line: Ernest Hemingway, pp. 216–217</p>
</blockquote>
<p>Do you ever plan ahead for something, whether cooking dinner or a lab experiment, by laying all of your tools, ingredients, and instructions out ahead of time? That way, when you are ready to get started there’s no hunting for the things you need or worries that you’ve forgotten something.</p>
<p>As a bonus, having everything ready to go can also help prompt or encourage you to get started.</p>
<p>A favorite method of Earnest Hemingway, that’s essentially what the set-up method for drafting is all about.</p>
<h2 id="how-does-the-set-up-method-work">How does the set up method work?</h2>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Stop a writing session when things are going well.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Leave a paragraph, sentence, or even word(!) unfinished.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Next writing session, re-read where you left off.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Start writing by finishing what you started.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Stop while things are still going well.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Like an informal writing prompt, this process can help get your writing juices flowing with little effort, breaking the inertia that often keeps a writing session from getting started.</p>
<h2 id="when-should-i-use-the-set-up-method">When should I use the set-up method?</h2>
<p>The set-up method pairs well with timed writing sessions, like the breaks during a Pomodoro or the end of a longer block. Instead of feeling frustrated that you have to stop when things are going well, you can use the set-up method to ensure that your next block of writing time begins efficiently.</p>
<p>This method may work well for people who tend to work until they hit burnout, exhausting themselves so much that they require days before their next writing block. Stopping early leaves a bit of gas in the tank, or words in the brain, which enables you to restart more easily than if you left it empty.</p>
<p>While interesting, this method is a potentially tricky one to make work. People with ADHD (<a href="https://alliancescc.github.io/post/adhd-writing-tips/">like myself</a>) will likely have mixed results, depending on how well each project sticks in their brain between sessions.</p>
<h2 id="what-if-i-forget-between-writing-sessions">What if I forget between writing sessions?</h2>
<p>If you try out this method of drafting but find yourself forgetting where you wanted to go with your writing between sessions, try making some notes in the document before you close it. Either in bullets below where you’ve been working or in a comment off to the side, jot down a few essential points about what you wanted to cover next so that you have a reminder for next time.</p>
<h2 id="see-it-at-work">See it at work</h2>
<blockquote class="bluesky-embed" data-bluesky-uri="at://did:plc:w3fckef2ovq4rexxpqizsp4y/app.bsky.feed.post/3l2jivfli3e2i" data-bluesky-cid="bafyreicmqxip4c2bk5nvski5ys73q624dx5pdkmmc6mfztfzm7hh3l7h4y"><p lang="en">It helps when I know what to write the next day. Yesterday, I outlined arguments in bullet points—today, I just explained, cited evidence, added analysis, and voila! Much easier than days when I have to start from scratch.
#AcWri #AcademicSky #writing</p>— Haleema Saadia (<a href="https://bsky.app/profile/did:plc:w3fckef2ovq4rexxpqizsp4y?ref_src=embed">@haleemasaadia.bsky.social</a>) <a href="https://bsky.app/profile/did:plc:w3fckef2ovq4rexxpqizsp4y/post/3l2jivfli3e2i?ref_src=embed">Aug 25, 2024 at 1:59 AM</a></blockquote><script async src="https://embed.bsky.app/static/embed.js" charset="utf-8"></script>
<h2 id="resources">Resources</h2>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://lithub.com/7-methods-for-writing-your-first-draft/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">7 Methods for Writing Your First Draft</a></li>
</ul>
<hr>
<p><strong>The <a href="https://alliancescc.github.io/post/draft_methods_intro/">introduction and full list</a> of methods for writing the first manuscript draft.</strong></p>

item.title: Three Tips to Organize Thesis and Article Sources

<script>
  (function(w, d, t, h, s, n) {
    w.FlodeskObject = n;

      (w[n].q = w[n].q || []).push(arguments);
    };
    w[n] = w[n] || fn;
    var f = d.getElementsByTagName(t)[0];
    var v = '?v=' + Math.floor(new Date().getTime() / (120 * 1000)) * 60;
    var sm = d.createElement(t);
    sm.async = true;
    sm.type = 'module';
    sm.src = h + s + '.mjs' + v;
    f.parentNode.insertBefore(sm, f);
    var sn = d.createElement(t);
    sn.async = true;
    sn.noModule = true;
    sn.src = h + s + '.js' + v;
    f.parentNode.insertBefore(sn, f);
  })(window, document, 'script', 'https://assets.flodesk.com', '/universal', 'fd');

<script>
  window.fd('form:handle', {
    formId: '[61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4]',
    rootEl: '.ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4',
  });
</script>

<p>Whether for a dissertation, thesis, or class research paper, a literature review may expose you to hundreds of research papers that could contribute to your understanding of the field and possibly even be cited in a manuscript. So how do you keep track of these sources?</p>
<p>Here, I’ll describe three options for you to consider: keep an annotated bibliography, use spreadsheets, and use a citation management software.</p>
<h1 id="tip-1-keep-an-annotated-bibliography">Tip 1: Keep an Annotated Bibliography</h1>
<p>An annotated bibliography is going to be a list of the sources that you’ve read along with important notes to explain the source’s importance and relevance to your research. While some people do this by hand, that can be laborious, particularly when you are searching for a source after the fact. My suggestion for the modern annotated bibliography is to use a searchable format such as Word, Rmarkdown, OneNote, EndNote, etc. These options allow you to easily re-reference a source and (re)identify sources that talk about particular concepts. To maximize your annotated bibliography, there are several key components to include in each entry (and <a href="https://alliancescc.github.io/uploads/Annotated_bibliography.pdf">here’s a worksheet</a>):</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p><strong>Citation</strong> — In addition to the author(s) and year of publication, you should also make a note of the doi (so you can find it later using <a href="">https://doi.org/[insert doi]</a>), and the filename of the pdf. The filename is especially important since it allows you to find the pdf you already have, without opening 20 files one-by-one.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Methods</strong> — Are any of the methods used especially relevant to your work? This might be because you need the protocol, they are key to interpreting the data, and/or are insufficient (i.e., they provide an opportunity for you to improve the field).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Results</strong> — What are the key results and findings? What figure is central to their story?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Limitations</strong> — What are the limitations of the research? What could be done differently to improve the robustness of the research?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Your thoughts</strong> — What do you think about the paper? Use this as an opportunity to present your unfiltered thoughts, feelings, musings, and big ideas. That way you can find them later.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Follow up</strong> — Are there any references that you should read in the future?</p>
</li>
</ul>
<h1 id="tip-2-keep-a-spreadsheet">Tip 2: Keep a Spreadsheet</h1>
<p>Spreadsheets are another great option for keeping track of the sources you’ve identified in a searchable and easy to skim format. In this case, you would likely include more granular information about the source’s origins, citations, accessibility, etc. However, what you include may depend on how you plan to use the document.</p>
<p>For example, Dr. Raul Pacheco-Vega uses a <a href="https://www.raulpacheco.org/2016/06/synthesizing-different-bodies-of-work-in-your-literature-review-the-conceptual-synthesis-excel-dump-technique/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">“Conceptual Synthesis Excel Dump”</a>. In addition to basic citation information, Dr. Pacheco-Vega includes columns to capture his thoughts on each references as well as cross references and potential quotations. It’s very much like a horizontally organized annotated bibliography.</p>
<p>For a more basic compilation of sources, Eastern Washington University has a <a href="https://research.ewu.edu/c.php?g=53632&p=2986487" target="_blank" rel="noopener">sample chart</a> that you can use to build your own and Kathleen Clarke <a href="https://www.insidehighered.com/blogs/gradhacker/organizing-your-literature-spreadsheet-style#" target="_blank" rel="noopener">describes</a> a slightly more intricate method that links spreadsheet entries to easy file identification. More visual, or more easily overwhelmed, writers might consider adding a color-coordination system to their spreadsheets.</p>
<h1 id="tip-3-use-a-citation-management-system">Tip 3: Use a Citation Management System</h1>
<p>Citation management systems can be great tools for keeping track of relevant sources. I used to recommend Mendeley, however, it was put behind a paywall and underwent changes that make it more difficult to use and export your references if needed.</p>
<p>The open source (free) tool, <a href="https://www.zotero.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Zotero</a> is now one of the best options available for tracking and organizing sources. Not only does it have a browser extension to directly import references as you find them, it has an extensive reference and bibliography generation system. These can be easily formatted for text editors and used directly with Word, LibreOffice, and Google Docs. Zotero also features some handy organization and collaboration tools.</p>
<p>The more visual academics might want to consider <a href="https://www.diigo.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Diigo</a>. With both free and paid options, this program features tools to tag, archive, annotate, organize, and even share your online research (much like Zotero does). The most innovative tool, however, is one that enables you to sort your sources into a structured outline, potentially allowing you to more easily identify weak or understudied parts of your research.</p>
<h2 id="resources">Resources</h2>
<ul>
<li>
<p><a href="https://beryliveylibrary.wordpress.com/2018/02/13/organize-research/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">What’s the Best Way to Organize My Research?</a> | A librarian breaks down how to approach and organize your literature review process.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="https://www.insidehighered.com/blogs/gradhacker/organizing-your-literature-spreadsheet-style#" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Organizing Your Literature: Spreadsheet Style</a> | Describes an adaptable, nested spreadsheet organization system and how it can link to and help organize your file storage.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="https://habitsofatravellingarchaeologist.com/tips-for-organizing-sources-for-research-papers/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Tips for Organizing Sources for Research Papers</a> | A basic review of the types of sources, how to get your literature review started, and some potential ways to stay organized.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JLhbTnmdgvo" target="_blank" rel="noopener">4 Must-Have Tools to Find and Organize Research Articles for a Literature Review</a> | A video with tips on using Elicit, Research Rabbit, Notion, and Zotero together to gather and organize your research.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="https://www.lifewire.com/organize-research-3483046" target="_blank" rel="noopener">15 Best Free Web Tools to Organize Your Research</a> | Broken into two lists of web tools: one for research and study and the second for writing.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bch9JLF70pc" target="_blank" rel="noopener">How to Organize Research Articles</a> | A non-traditional approach using a knowledge monetization platform (Kahana) to organize and share your academic research (for free).</p>
</li>
</ul>

item.title: Scientific Writing is Messy. That’s Perfect.
item.description:

</div>
<script>
  (function(w, d, t, h, s, n) {
    w.FlodeskObject = n;
    var fn = function() {
      (w[n].q = w[n].q || []).push(arguments);
    };
    w[n] = w[n] || fn;
    var f = d.getElementsByTagName(t)[0];
    var v = '?v=' + Math.floor(new Date().getTime() / (120 * 1000)) * 60;
    var sm = d.createElement(t);
    sm.async = true;
    sm.type = 'module';
    sm.src = h + s + '.mjs' + v;
    f.parentNode.insertBefore(sm, f);
    var sn = d.createElement(t);
    sn.async = true;
    sn.noModule = true;
    sn.src = h + s + '.js' + v;
    f.parentNode.insertBefore(sn, f);
  })(window, document, 'script', 'https://assets.flodesk.com', '/universal', 'fd');
</script>
<script>
  window.fd('form:handle', {
    formId: '[61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4]',
    rootEl: '.ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4',
  });
</script>

<p>The scientific writing process can be summarized in five steps: prewriting, drafting, revising, editing, and finally… publication. It seems straightforward, but also… overwhelming. Especially when you’re tasked with starting at the beginning.</p>
<p>The good news is that while writing is a lot of work, it can be made more approachable. This post is the first in a series that will explore the writing process and break it down into actionable pieces, with an emphasis on writing in the biological and biosciences.</p>
<p>We’ll begin by describing the overall writing process and workflow.</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Prewriting - generate ideas, identify evidence and sources, and craft outlines</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Drafting - transform the outline into logically connected sentences and paragraphs, add evidence</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Revising - reorganize the draft, add evidence, eliminate tangents</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Editing - correct misspellings and grammar, check citations and figures</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Publication - submit for grading (or peer review)</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>And so, the general process appears to be linear.</p>














<figure  id="figure-what-we-think-the-writing-process-is-like-linear">
  <div class="d-flex justify-content-center">
    <div class="w-100" ><img alt="What we think the writing process is like. Linear." srcset="
               /post/writing_process/writing_process_linear_hu505d8ad4a4021a1134ad263daf931d17_5271_22986136575dea8c4d0e8184236fc0f9.webp 400w,
               /post/writing_process/writing_process_linear_hu505d8ad4a4021a1134ad263daf931d17_5271_d9df44e22242f5eb3863a99210e4128d.webp 760w,
               /post/writing_process/writing_process_linear_hu505d8ad4a4021a1134ad263daf931d17_5271_1200x1200_fit_q75_h2_lanczos_3.webp 1200w"
               src="https://alliancescc.github.io/post/writing_process/writing_process_linear_hu505d8ad4a4021a1134ad263daf931d17_5271_22986136575dea8c4d0e8184236fc0f9.webp"
               width="344"
               height="726"
               loading="lazy" data-zoomable /></div>
  </div><figcaption>
      What we think the writing process is like. Linear.
    </figcaption></figure>
<p>But in practice, the effective writing process is quite a bit messier (image 2). For instance, after writing a first draft, the author often identifies topics that need more elaboration and/or evidence, which send them back through the prewriting and drafting steps. Even after a manuscript is done and submitted to a research advisor or reviewer, it often comes back with requests for revision. To accomplish those revisions, the author may need to revisit the prewriting and drafting steps again, followed by revising and editing for resubmission.</p>














<figure  id="figure-a-better-representation-of-the-writing-process-iterative">
  <div class="d-flex justify-content-center">
    <div class="w-100" ><img alt="A better representation of the writing process. Iterative." srcset="
               /post/writing_process/writing_process_messy_hu737c7f8e29dd2bae9f0b8b1a5bf0de99_9007_0b2a8596edf16f56c541857c0a49acb1.webp 400w,
               /post/writing_process/writing_process_messy_hu737c7f8e29dd2bae9f0b8b1a5bf0de99_9007_43513328fc002e3fb67e7137f599f7fd.webp 760w,
               /post/writing_process/writing_process_messy_hu737c7f8e29dd2bae9f0b8b1a5bf0de99_9007_1200x1200_fit_q75_h2_lanczos_3.webp 1200w"
               src="https://alliancescc.github.io/post/writing_process/writing_process_messy_hu737c7f8e29dd2bae9f0b8b1a5bf0de99_9007_0b2a8596edf16f56c541857c0a49acb1.webp"
               width="586"
               height="609"
               loading="lazy" data-zoomable /></div>
  </div><figcaption>
      A better representation of the writing process. Iterative.
    </figcaption></figure>
<p>At first glance, the real writing process may seem even more overwhelming. After all, how are you supposed to know when to move forward or backward? How will you know when you’re done?</p>
<p>These are valid fears, and the beauty of an iterative writing process is that you don’t really have to answer them. Approaching writing as an iterative process, as opposed to linear, has multiple advantages. Some of these include:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Reduced pressure for first drafts,</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>More realistic writing expectations,</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>More accurate writing timeline, and</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Having sections in different stages of the process allows for workload flexibility.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Scientific writing is an act of creativity that requires freedom to think, synthesize, and explore new ideas. Removing the pressure for the first draft to be perfect, or near perfect, allows you as a writer to start the writing process more creatively with bigger, messier ideas. As the ideas are refined, they might lead to unexpected connections and conclusions, but it’s hard to know unless they are given voice.</p>
<p>Additionally, because you begin the process knowing that prewriting, drafting, and revising will be revisited, there is less pressure for each step to be “complete” before moving on to the next. Set goals for the amount of time of words that you’ll spend on each step and when you’re done, start over. The more you write, the more accurate expectations you can develop for the time and effort spent at each step, leading to more accurate writing timelines.</p>
<p>An added bonus is that you can break down the writing task into smaller chunks, and work through the writing process for each individual section. If you have sections at varying stages (e.g., introduction is in prewriting, methods are in revising, discussion is in drafting), then you have freedom in the type of writing you will accomplish on any given day. Tired of putting words on the page? Read literature and work on prewriting the introduction. Mentally burnt out but still want to make progress? Add citations to the methods section.</p>
<blockquote>
<p>“ Writing is not a linear process, like following a recipe to bake a cake.” Teaching Elementary School Students to Be Effective Writers, <a href="https://ies.ed.gov/ncee/wwc/Docs/PracticeGuide/writing_pg_062612.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Pg 14</a></p>
</blockquote>
<p>If the demands of a linear writing process seem overwhelming to you. It’s understandable. Approaching writing as an iterative process may help overcome some of the mental obstacles in the way of your next writing task. This brief overview of the writing process will be followed by posts exploring each step in more detail and providing strategies to tackle them. For now, if your best laid writing plans aren’t working out, don’t feel alone. Writing is messy. And that’s perfect.</p>
<h2 id="resources">Resources:</h2>
<p><a href="https://punctumbooks.com/titles/how-we-write/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">How We Write: Thirteen Ways of Looking at a Blank Page</a> | Essays exploring the messiness of writing and the evolution of each author’s own process.</p>
<p><a href="https://writing.dartmouth.edu/teaching/first-year-writing-pedagogies-methods-design/teaching-writing-process" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Teaching Writing as Process</a> | Defines writing process vs. product, thoroughly describes process writing and gives tips for facilitating a trainee’s writing process.</p>
<p><a href="https://saylordotorg.github.io/text_business-english-for-success/s11-the-writing-process-how-do-i-b.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Chapter 7: The Writing Process: How Do I Begin?</a> | An extensive description of each step in the writing process with tips, techniques, examples, and prompts.</p>
<p><a href="https://sites.google.com/site/writingwithpete/the-writing-process" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The Art of Academic Writing - The Writing Process</a> | An engaging description of the writing process that addresses two common misconceptions and procrastination.</p>
<p><a href="https://youtu.be/_X3S43LqVi8?feature=shared" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The Writing Process: Exploring Different Writers’ Processes</a> | A video featuring a brief overview followed by several examples of processes used by famous creative authors.</p>
<p><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vKRmsjT-iIE" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Six Steps to Developing Your Writing Process</a> | A webinar recording with a longer walk-through of the writing process that uses an essay prompt to demonstrate progression.</p>
<p><a href="https://youtu.be/vRJuwzCfix4?feature=shared" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The Writing Process and Process Writing</a> | A video that defines process-oriented approaches and gives a brief overview of process writing.</p>

item.title: 16 Writing Tips for ADHD Brains
item.description:

<blockquote>
<p>“There’s no rule on how it is to write… Sometimes it comes easily and perfectly. Sometimes it is like drilling rock and then blasting it out with charges.” — <em>Earnest Hemmingway on Writing</em></p>
</blockquote>
<p>Writing when you have ADHD is particularly onerous. Sometimes you’ve been ruminating or feel inspired and the words just flow on to the page (much like this blog post). Other times just the thought of working on a writing assignment sends your brain into a tailspin. So how can you make progress when the deadline isn’t in two hours and getting words on the page feels like <a href="https://alliancescc.github.io/post/writing-with-adhd/">fishing barehanded</a>?</p>
<p>This post contains 16 suggestions split into two sections:</p>
<ul>
<li>9 ideas for emergencies and</li>
<li>7 ideas for planning ahead to make consistent progress on large projects.</li>
</ul>
<p>Some of these are things that have worked for me, others are suggestions from other ADHD writers. Remember: your mileage may vary (depending on the project, your brain, hormones, etc).</p>
<h2 id="writing-emergencies">Writing Emergencies</h2>
<p>If you’re stuck and need help right now:</p>
<p><strong>Adapt the pomodoro</strong> — Set a timer for 20 minutes and try to type a few sentences (consider starting with the <a href="https://alliancescc.github.io/post/draft_methods_freewrite/">Freewrite Method</a> if you need). Write extraneous thoughts on a spare sheet of paper to get them out of your head, which can help attempts to refocus. Once you get going, dispense with the timer except for when you STOP writing (bathroom, food breaks), then set it to remind yourself to get back to writing.</p>
<p><strong>Put your headphones in/on</strong> — If that doesn’t work, start a good playlist. I find that I prefer certain music when I’m writing, another when I’m coding, etc. Find the genere that feels inspiring and try to feed off of its energy to get started. <a href="https://music.youtube.com/channel/UCRbwwfdLqg8UR9SZdqRuxOw?si=rN5UD42ov27f_j-U" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Here</a> are some of my favorites, most of which have no vocals.</p>
<p><strong>Go off grid</strong> — Turn off notifications, wifi, everything, then sit and stare at the page. If you aren’t writing, you aren’t doing anything else either so you might as well write.</p>
<p><strong>Find what’s possible</strong> — This is particularly helpful with larger writing projects that have multiple pieces in varying stages of completion. Maybe putting words on the page is impossible today but tackling comments from your advisor is doable. Revisions and edits are valid, important parts of the <a href="https://alliancescc.github.io/post/writing_process/">writing process</a>, too.</p>
<p><strong>Start small</strong> — Identify the smallest, most specific writing goal(s) possible and frame it as a question. Answering that question may naturally lead into more. E.g., what are the characteristics of <em>Bacillus anthracis</em>? (Answer: <em>B. anthracis</em> is a gram positive, spore-forming bacterium. It is the causative agent of…)</p>
<p><strong>Embrace stimulation</strong> — Find a mindless task (washing dishes, driving, folding laundry) and do it in silence instead of playing the radio, tv, or your phone. Think about what you’ve written so far and what you would like to write next. Think about your project until the words are itching to get on the page.</p>
<p><strong>Harness novelty</strong> — Go somewhere new to work, whether it be a coffee shop, library, or co-working space, find and control novelty in a place with the right amount of stimulation to let you focus on your writing.</p>
<p><strong>Try <a href="https://alliancescc.github.io/post/draft_methods_freewrite/">freewriting</a></strong> — This writing method can really help if your brain feels stuck since writing about what you’re having trouble with can help get you to what you’re supposed to be writing.</p>
<p><strong>Go for a walk</strong> — Letting ADHD bodies move often allows their brains the space to create. The problem is that you can’t walk and write at the same time. Or can you? Consider using Google Docs, a recorder app, or some form of dictation software to record yourself writing out loud as you walk. When you get back to the desk, transcribe/transfer it to your manuscript and now you have something to work with.</p>
<h2 id="tips-for-writing-ahead">Tips for Writing Ahead</h2>
<p>If you’re thinking about how to make consistent progress on a project without leaving it to the last minute:</p>
<p><strong>Rotate projects</strong> — Executive function isn’t exactly a strong suit for people with ADHD this may seem a counterintuitive suggestion, but consider maintaining multiple projects. Because our interest in a project can come in fits and bursts, having multiple projects that you can pick up and put down as your interest varies means that even if one seems impossible to tackle, you may have the brainspace or inspiration for another of your projects. Rotating through them can satisfy the need for novelty while maintaining momentum (and fostering <a href="https://alliancescc.github.io/post/draft_methods_incubation/">incubation</a>).</p>
<p><strong>Body double</strong> — Find an accountability buddy or group that you can co-work with, either in-person or online. People with ADHD tend to be socially motivated. Having another person trying to focus while you’re trying to focus can sometimes enhance your ability to focus!</p>
<p><strong>The <a href="https://alliancescc.github.io/post/draft_methods_setup/">set-up method</a></strong> — Plan ahead and stop while things are flowing. Leave a word, sentence, or paragraph unwritten so that you know right where to start next time. As great as it can feel to get words on the page, it can help to stop writing before you burn out.</p>
<p><strong>Keep the trash</strong> — Instead of completely deleting phrases and/or paragraphs that don’t work, keep a separate document for each of your projects where you can move those snippets. When you feel stuck, skim through the “trash” for anything that inspires.</p>
<p><strong>Make a checklist</strong> — In other words, make an <a href="https://alliancescc.github.io/post/why_outline/">outline</a>. Check off or cross out each topic as you cover it so you know what’s missing and avoid feeling the immense overwhelm of WRITING with smaller topics. If long checklists overwhelm you, split it into smaller bites that you can then allocate to different writing sessions.</p>
<p><strong>Embrace spurts<sup id="fnref:1"><a href="#fn:1" class="footnote-ref" role="doc-noteref">1</a></sup></strong> — Keep the document open on your desktop. When a good sentence, phrase, etc. pops in your brain, tab over and write it down before you forget! This could be particularly helpful for people who work at the bench. Repetitive tasks allow your mind to wander and “write” as you work. Having the document open enables jotting those thoughts down as they occur, making progress easier.</p>
<p><strong>Allow processing time</strong> — All brains need time to process and digest information after gathering it. I suspect that ADHD and other neurodivergent brains need a bit more time so consider allowing yourself a week or two between when you finish prewriting and start drafting.</p>
<p><strong>Got any tips to add? Let me know on <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/adahagan/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">LinkedIn</a> or <a href="https://bsky.app/profile/dradawrites.bsky.social" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Bluesky</a>!</strong></p>
<h2 id="resources">Resources</h2>
<ul>
<li>
<p><a href="https://www.hackingyouradhd.com/podcast/qampa-writing-past-the-hard-parts" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Q&A: Writing Past the Hard Parts</a> | A short podcast episode with thoughts about what makes writing hard and how to get past the hard parts.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="https://www.reddit.com/r/writing/comments/13dm067/pro_writers_with_adhd_what_are_your_tips_to_get/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">ADHD Writing Tips on Reddit</a></p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/tips-for-those-who-struggle-with-executive-functioning" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Tips to Stay Organized and Focused when Struggling with Executive Functioning</a></p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="https://larawillard.com/2018/03/02/tools-tricks-for-writers-with-adhd/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Tool & Tricks for Writers with ADHD</a></p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="https://theadhdacademic.weebly.com/learning--adhd-blog-posts/writing-tips-for-those-who-cant-organize-focus-and-motivate" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Writing Tips from the ADHD Academic</a></p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="https://www.additudemag.com/assistive-technology-writing-tools-for-students-with-adhd/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Assistive Writing Technology</a></p>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="footnotes" role="doc-endnotes">
<hr>
<ol>
<li id="fn:1">
<p>A post to describe this method in more detail is on its way! <a href="#fnref:1" class="footnote-backref" role="doc-backlink">↩︎</a></p>
</li>
</ol>
</div>

item.title: Writing with ADHD (Or, Fishing Barehanded)
item.description:

    var v = '?v=' + Math.floor(new Date().getTime() / (120 * 1000)) * 60;
    var sm = d.createElement(t);
    sm.async = true;
    sm.type = 'module';
    sm.src = h + s + '.mjs' + v;
    f.parentNode.insertBefore(sm, f);
    var sn = d.createElement(t);
    sn.async = true;
    sn.noModule = true;
    sn.src = h + s + '.js' + v;
    f.parentNode.insertBefore(sn, f);
  })(window, document, 'script', 'https://assets.flodesk.com', '/universal', 'fd');

<script>
  window.fd('form:handle', {
    formId: '[61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4]',
    rootEl: '.ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4',
  });
</script>

<p>Writing when you have ADHD is like fishing barehanded. You know the words are there, you can see them, maybe even touch them. But as soon as you try to grasp them, they slip away.</p>
<p>At least, that’s what it seems like to me.</p>
<p>I was only recently (within the last few years) diagnosed with ADHD. Of course, in hindsight, I can see it. I see the accommodations and coping mechanisms that I was fortunate enough to stumble upon, that allowed me to succeed. I see the missed opportunities, broken or neglected relationships, and unfulfilled promises. I also see the big ideas, dreams, creativity, and innovation that I often tried to pursue, with mixed results.</p>
<p>When it comes to writing, I finally understand (at least a bit) why I struggled and why what worked, worked.</p>
<ul>
<li>Writer’s block was often the absence of novelty or an inability to organize my thoughts.</li>
<li>Body doubling and shared workspaces curbed impulses and provided a degree of accountability.</li>
<li>Caffeine calmed me.</li>
<li>New places to write were a source of controlled novelty.</li>
</ul>
<p>I wish I could say that I’ve figured out all the tips and tricks to writing with ADHD, but I can’t. In fact, this post is one of my first, successful creative endeavors in the last 18 months because my brain has absolutely balked at writing. It’s a feeling that is nearly impossible to explain. I could do other things, like editing and data analysis, but not write. Not a good look for someone whose business is writing.</p>
<p>It’s been an exceedingly frustrating experience. But an enlightening one, I suppose, now that the dam has finally broken.</p>
<p>I’ve finally realized that whatever’s happening in my brain, my approach to life, work, and writing is fundamentally different than most. And those differences have, and will continue to be, reflected in the way that I teach, talk, and write about academic writing. I’m now making the choice to be more cognizant and intentional about it.</p>
<p>So this post serves multiple functions:</p>
<ol>
<li>It’s an expression of empathy and understanding for other ADHD/neurodivergent brains that need to write but just won’t.</li>
<li>It’s a notice that I plan to add services and content geared to ADHD/neurodivergent writers.</li>
<li>It’s a grain of salt applicable to <em>all</em> content and advice that I provide.</li>
<li>And it’s a reminder that even if I stop posting here and/or on social media that I do (and Alliance does) still exist and am/will be happy to help however I can.</li>
</ol>
<p><em>For now, check out this <a href="https://alliancescc.github.io/post/adhd-writing-tips/">list of brain hacks</a> I compiled for writing with ADHD.</em></p>
<h2 id="resources">Resources</h2>
<ul>
<li>
<p><a href="https://theadhdacademic.weebly.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The ADHD Academic</a> | A blog exploring how to cope with ADHD in the academy.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="https://www.additudemag.com/assistive-technology-writing-tools-for-students-with-adhd/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Assistive Writing Technology</a> | A list of digital tools to help learners with ADHD</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="https://www.helensword.com/helen-sword-blog/supporting-neurodiverse-writers" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Supporting Neurodiverse Writers</a> | A thoughtful summary of a discussion and workshop focused on neurodiversity and neurodivergence in scholarly writing with tools for managing the mentor/mentee writing relationship.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="https://academiccoach.info/blog/writing-academically-when-you-are-neurodiverse" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Writing Academically When You are Neurodiverse</a> | Concrete examples that may help articulate your needs and how they can be met.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="https://scholarstudioblog.wordpress.com/2015/11/14/hacking-graduate-school-with-learning-differences/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Hacking Graduate School For Neurodiverse Learners: Part 1 of 3</a> | Questions to help trainees identify why they might be struggling with examples of helpful accommodations.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="https://scholarstudioblog.wordpress.com/2015/11/15/working-with-neurodiverse-graduate-students-ideas-for-faculty/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advising Neurodiverse Thesis and Dissertation Students: Part 2 of 3</a> | Addresses common myths about trainee help and offers suggestions for advisors to help neurodiverse trainees succeed.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="https://dept.writing.wisc.edu/blog/how-we-actually-write-neurodiversity-writing-process-and-writing-instruction/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">How We [Actually] Write: Neurodiversity, Writing Process, and Writing Instruction</a> | A writing center tutor discusses how writing is a neurodiverse process that requires more flexibility in its instruction and execution.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="https://open.spotify.com/episode/04jmbP9fPOh8Zatzp2BJbu?si=38509f5fdbdc4814" target="_blank" rel="noopener">How to Write with ADHD and Coach Skye Waterson</a> | A writing podcast interviews an ADHD researcher about writing her dissertation and how the struggles of an ADHD writer differs from those without.</p>
</li>
</ul>

item.title: How to Get Scientific Writing Editing & Consulting Paid For

<script>
  (function(w, d, t, h, s, n) {
    w.FlodeskObject = n;
    var fn = function() {
      (w[n].q = w[n].q || []).push(arguments);
    };
    w[n] = w[n] || fn;
    var f = d.getElementsByTagName(t)[0];
    var v = '?v=' + Math.floor(new Date().getTime() / (120 * 1000)) * 60;
    var sm = d.createElement(t);
    sm.async = true;
    sm.type = 'module';
    sm.src = h + s + '.mjs' + v;
    f.parentNode.insertBefore(sm, f);
    var sn = d.createElement(t);
    sn.async = true;
    sn.noModule = true;
    sn.src = h + s + '.js' + v;
    f.parentNode.insertBefore(sn, f);
  })(window, document, 'script', 'https://assets.flodesk.com', '/universal', 'fd');
</script>
<script>
  window.fd('form:handle', {
    formId: '[61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4]',
    rootEl: '.ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4',
  });
</script>

<p>Writing is one of the most ubiquitous components of academia. You write to get grants, publish papers, and get promoted. Academic institutions are aware of the necessity of writing, which is why many provide professional writing services at reduced, or no, cost. But undergrad heavy institutions can skew writer expertise toward term papers and reports; writing services may only be available to students, not postdocs or faculty; or perhaps the exact services that you need aren’t available.</p>
<p>In these situations, you may need to look outside of your institutional offerings to find a  writing consultant or editors. And we aren’t cheap :/ ….</p>
<p>The good news is that many institutions and funding agencies have ways for you to pay for this help WITHOUT reaching into your own pocket. Below are examples of ways to access funding for writing help. It’s largely organized by academic position (trainee vs faculty).But broadly speaking, <strong>consultants (e.g., editors) are allowable costs for almost all research grants!</strong></p>
<h1 id="trainees-graduate-students--postdocs">Trainees (graduate students & postdocs)</h1>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Many graduate and postdoctoral programs offer mini grants and similar funding mechanisms for professional development activities (e.g., <a href="https://alliancescc.github.io/science-writing-labs/">Science Writing Labs</a>, <a href="https://alliancescc.github.io/writing_services/">webinars</a>)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Institutional seed grants and other small research grants usually consider consultants to be an allowable cost and will pay for help to either publish a paper or write another grant proposal (e.g., <a href="https://alliancescc.github.io/writing_services/">editing services</a>)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Training grants, future independent research grants, and similar career grants often have a focus on professional development and will allow funds to be spent on such training activities. Some may only allow funds to be used for research grant proposal development; to be sure, check with the grant manager. See the “Faculty” section for more information on NIH trainee grants (e.g., NRSA, Ks).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Professional and scientific societies often have funds set aside for members to advance their careers. Check to see if yours have any mini grants for professional development available. Local and/or student chapters of such societies are also a good place to look for professional development funds. Remember, even if funds for individuals aren’t available, you can still ask about sponsored workshops or seminars. A couple of societies with professional development-related grants include:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p><a href="https://asm.org/Fellowships/Career-Development-Grants-for-Postdoctoral-Women" target="_blank" rel="noopener">American Society for Microbiology</a></p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="https://www.aauw.org/resources/programs/fellowships-grants/current-opportunities/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">American Association of University Women</a></p>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>
<p>Your PI/research mentor may have access to two types of funding. Their start-up/discretionary fund, which generally has very few restrictions, and any research grants. See the “Faculty” section below for more detailed information about the costs allowed by most NIH & NSF grants. Internal/institutional grants will vary.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Similarly, many departments and/or programs have a pot of discretionary funds. Ask your chair or director if you can receive a one-time professional development grant. Alternately, ask if they would be willing to host a professional development workshop/webinar for department/program trainees.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<h1 id="faculty">Faculty</h1>
<h2 id="nih-awards">NIH Awards</h2>
<h3 id="general-cost-considerationhttpsgrantsnihgovgrantspolicynihgpshtml5section_779_allowability_of_costs_activitieshtm"><a href="https://grants.nih.gov/grants/policy/nihgps/html5/section_7/7.9_allowability_of_costs_activities.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener">General Cost Consideration:</a></h3>
<p><strong>7.9 Professional Services Costs</strong> (i.e., Consultants)</p>
<p>“<strong>Costs of professional and consultant services rendered by persons who are members of a particular profession or possess a special skill,</strong> and who are not officers or employees of the non-Federal entity, are allowable, subject to paragraphs (b) and (c) below when reasonable in relation to the services rendered and which not contingent upon recovery of the costs from the Federal government.</p>
<p>“(b) The necessity of contracting for the service, considering the non-Federal entity’s capability in the particular area. (<em>i.e., your needs can’t be fully met by existing institutional support</em>)</p>
<p>(c) The past pattern of such costs, particularly in the years prior to Federal awards.”</p>
<h3 id="researcher-career-k-awardshttpsgrantsnihgovgrantspolicynihgpshtml5section_1212_research_career_development_k_awardshtm"><a href="https://grants.nih.gov/grants/policy/nihgps/html5/section_12/12_research_career_development_k_awards.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Researcher Career “K” Awards:</a></h3>
<p>Including: Institutional, Individual Mentors & Non-Mentored, & Career Transition</p>
<p><strong>12.8.3 Proposal Preparation Costs</strong></p>
<p>“Mentored CDA programs provide support with a goal of leading to research independence for an individual. Since research independence is achieved through applying for other research support, consistent with these objectives, <strong>it is allowable for effort devoted to proposal preparation costs for subsequent research support to be charged to a mentored CDA award.</strong> This can be considered part of the awarded effort commitment of the mentored CDA or an increase to that commitment with the allowable salary provided as applicable.”</p>
<h3 id="ruth-l-kirschstein-national-research-service-awardshttpsgrantsnihgovgrantspolicynihgpshtml5section_111129_allowable_and_unallowable_costshtm"><a href="https://grants.nih.gov/grants/policy/nihgps/html5/section_11/11.2.9_allowable_and_unallowable_costs.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Ruth L. Kirschstein National Research Service Awards:</a></h3>
<p><strong>11.2.9</strong> Stipend and travel only.</p>
<h3 id="support-of-scientific-meetings-conference-grantshttpsgrantsnihgovgrantspolicynihgpshtml5section_141410_allowable_and_unallowable_costshtm"><a href="https://grants.nih.gov/grants/policy/nihgps/html5/section_14/14.10_allowable_and_unallowable_costs.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Support of Scientific Meetings (Conference Grants):</a></h3>
<p><strong>14.10.1</strong> “Consultant Services. Grant funds may be used to pay consultant fees, including travel and supporting costs (per diem or, applicable, subsistence).”</p>
<h3 id="grants-to-foreign-organizations-international-organizations-and-domestic-grants-with-foreign-componentshttpsgrantsnihgovgrantspolicynihgpshtml5section_16166_allowable_and_unallowable_costshtm"><a href="https://grants.nih.gov/grants/policy/nihgps/html5/section_16/16.6_allowable_and_unallowable_costs.htm" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Grants to Foreign Organizations, International Organizations, and Domestic Grants with Foreign Components:</a></h3>
<p><strong>16.6</strong> “Awards to domestic organizations with a foreign or international consortium participant may include 8 percent of modified total direct costs, exclusive of tuition and related fees, direct expenditures for equipment, and subawards in excess of $25,000. These funds are paid to support the costs of compliance with federal requirements.”</p>
<h2 id="nsf-awards">NSF Awards</h2>
<h3 id="pappg-nsf-22-1-october-4-2021">PAPPG NSF 22-1 October 4, 2021</h3>
<p>The PAPPG, in conjunction with NSF’s Grant General Conditions, serves as the Foundation’ implementation of 2 CFR \S 200, Uniform Administrative Requirements, Cost Principles, and Audit Requirements for Federal Awards. If the PAPPG and NSF Grant Conditions are silent on a specific area covered by 2 CFR (S) 200, <em>the requirements specified in 2 CFR \S 200 must be followed.</em></p>
<h3 id="chapter-x---allowability-of-costshttpswwwnsfgovpubspolicydocspappg22_1pappg_10jsp"><a href="https://www.nsf.gov/pubs/policydocs/pappg22_1/pappg_10.jsp" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Chapter X - Allowability of Costs</a></h3>
<p>All costs charged to NSF awards meet the requirements of the cost principles contained in 2 CFR (S) 200, Subpart E.</p>
<p><a href="https://www.ecfr.gov/current/title-2/subtitle-A/chapter-II/part-200/subpart-E/subject-group-ECFRed1f39f9b3d4e72/section-200.459" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>200.459 Professional service costs</strong></a> - See NIH Awards: General Cost Considerations (above).</p>
<p><a href="https://www.nsf.gov/bfa/dia/policy/fedrtc/irtc/irtc_1021.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><strong>Special Conditions apply to International Research Terms and Conditions:</strong></a></p>
<p>“<strong>Costs for professional and consultant services, including those who are members of a particular profession or possess a special skill and who are not officers or employees of the performing organization, are allowable</strong> when reasonable in relation to the services rendered and when not contingent upon recovery of costs from NSF. If not included in the grant budget, anticipated services must be justified and information furnished on each individual’s expertise, primary organizational affiliation, normal daily compensation rate, and number of days of expected service. Consultant’s travel costs, including subsistence, may be included. If requested, the grantee must be able to justify that the proposed rate of pay is reasonable. Additional information on the allowability of consultant costs is available in 2 CFR (S) 200.456.”</p>

item.title: The 'Outline' Method for Scientific Writing
item.description:

  (function(w, d, t, h, s, n) {
    w.FlodeskObject = n;
    var fn = function() {
      (w[n].q = w[n].q || []).push(arguments);
    };
    w[n] = w[n] || fn;
    var f = d.getElementsByTagName(t)[0];
    var v = '?v=' + Math.floor(new Date().getTime() / (120 * 1000)) * 60;
    var sm = d.createElement(t);
    sm.async = true;
    sm.type = 'module';
    sm.src = h + s + '.mjs' + v;
    f.parentNode.insertBefore(sm, f);
    var sn = d.createElement(t);
    sn.async = true;
    sn.noModule = true;
    sn.src = h + s + '.js' + v;
    f.parentNode.insertBefore(sn, f);
  })(window, document, 'script', 'https://assets.flodesk.com', '/universal', 'fd');
</script>
<script>
  window.fd('form:handle', {
    formId: '[61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4]',
    rootEl: '.ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4',
  });
</script>

<p>The writing process consists of several steps: prewriting, drafting, revising, editing, and publication. The <a href="https://alliancescc.github.io/post/why_outline/">outline</a> is generated during the prewriting stage and, while necessary to describe the broad structure of an article, it is rarely revisited.</p>
<blockquote>
<p>The outline drafting method, however, expands on the original outline to structure the drafting process.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>Beginning with the original outlining of the topic, major supporting topics, and key points, this drafting process gradually increases the level of detail for each section. This continues until every potential paragraph has been outlined to the appropriate degree of detail. All appropriate definitions, explanations, descriptions, evidence, or examples should be included along with any quotes that might be incorporated within the text.</p>
<hr>
<blockquote>
<p><strong>Introduction</strong></p>
</blockquote>
<ul>
<li>The writing process</li>
<li>Prewriting
<ul>
<li>Outline</li>
<li>rarely revisited</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>This method expands the outline</li>
</ul>
<blockquote>
<p><strong>Description</strong></p>
</blockquote>
<ul>
<li>Increase the detail</li>
<li>outline each paragraph</li>
<li>Including more than facts</li>
<li>rewrite in full sentences</li>
<li>add transitions</li>
</ul>
<blockquote>
<p><strong>Conclusion</strong></p>
</blockquote>
<ul>
<li>Helps with
<ul>
<li>short bursts of writing</li>
<li>writer’s block</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>almost exactly match the outline</li>
<li>may require more transition revisions</li>
</ul>
<hr>
<p>When as much detail has been added as possible, each fragment of the detailed outline is rewritten as a full, and complete sentence. Given that each sentence and paragraph will be drafted in isolation, the essential final step in the outline drafting method is to add the appropriate transitions between paragraphs and statements.</p>
<hr>
<blockquote>
<p><strong>Introduction</strong></p>
</blockquote>
<ul>
<li>The writing process consists of several steps: prewriting, drafting, revising, editing, and publication.</li>
<li>The outline is generated during the prewriting stage.</li>
<li>The outline is rarely revisited.</li>
<li>The outline drafting method expands the outline to structure the drafting process.</li>
</ul>
<blockquote>
<p><strong>Description</strong></p>
</blockquote>
<ul>
<li>The original outline of the topic contains the major supporting topics and key points.</li>
<li>The level of detail for each section is gradually increased.</li>
<li>Each paragraph is outlined.</li>
<li>Include any definitions, explanations, descriptions, evidence, or examples along with any quotes that might be incorporated within the text.</li>
<li>Each fragment of the detailed outline is rewritten as a full sentence.</li>
<li>The final step is to add transitions between paragraphs and statements.</li>
</ul>
<blockquote>
<p><strong>Conclusion</strong></p>
</blockquote>
<ul>
<li>The outline drafting method is particularly helpful for those who work in short bursts and/or have severe writer’s block.</li>
<li>The complete first draft should follow the beginning outline (that you and your advisor agreed on) almost exactly.</li>
<li>The first draft may require more transition revisions than other drafting methods.</li>
</ul>
<hr>
<p>The outline drafting method is particularly helpful for those who can only work for short bursts and/or have severe writer’s block. The complete first draft should follow the beginning outline (that you and your advisor agreed on) almost exactly, though it may require more transition revisions than if it were written using other drafting methods.</p>
<h2 id="references">References</h2>
<p><a href="https://courses.lumenlearning.com/englishcomp1/chapter/video-moving-from-outline-to-draft/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Moving From Outline to Draft</a></p>
<p><a href="https://dept.writing.wisc.edu/wac/handout-from-outline-to-first-draft/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Handout: From Outline to First Draft</a></p>
<p><strong>The <a href="https://alliancescc.github.io/post/draft_methods_intro/">introduction and full list</a> of methods for writing the first manuscript draft.</strong></p>

item.title: The 'Refinery' Method for Scientific Writing
item.description:
The term “refine” is defined as the improvement of a process, theory, or machine through small changes. Accordingly, the refinery method of writing is drafting an article through multiple distinct versions, each of which has been altered from the previous version.

The first step of the refinery method is to write a complete draft of a section or blog post, start to finish. Don’t stress about how it begins, ends, or what happens in between. Once it’s written, read through it and note potential major changes.

Next, open a fresh word document or get a fresh piece of paper and rewrite the entire draft. This time, incorporate the noted changes as you write. Again, read through the freshly completed draft and note any major changes that you might like to make.

In (or on) a fresh document, again rewrite the entire draft. Once completed, again read and note any major changes. These steps can be completed any number of times, until the overall structure of the draft is satisfactory.

The refinery method is generally used when writing fiction, however, it can also be adapted to academic and/or scientific writing. I suggest using it when the overall structure or narrative doesn’t seem readily apparent. Getting the words onto paper in the order that comes most naturally enables their order and suitability to be evaluated.

References

7 Methods for Writing Your First Draft https://lithub.com/7-methods-for-writing-your-first-draft/

The introduction and full list of methods for writing the first manuscript draft.

item.title: The 'Freewrite' Method for Scientific Writing
item.description:

    formId: '[61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4]',
    rootEl: '.ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4',
  });
</script>

<p>Despite the importance of pre-writing <a href="https://alliancescc.github.io/post/draft_methods_warm_up/">warm ups</a>, we can’t always make it happen. Perhaps we were too preoccupied with another problem to focus during the warm up period. Or maybe a meeting ran over and we had to rush between tasks, skipping the warm up altogether.</p>
<blockquote>
<p>In any case, if you sit down to write and your mind is blank, try the freewrite method.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>Freewriting is a stream of consciousness method that can help direct your mind to the task at hand. Here’s how it works:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Sit down with an open word document.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Start typing anything that comes to mind.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Continue typing, and remind yourself what your writing task is.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Keep typing everything that goes through your mind.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Eventually this mental conversation will transition entirely to the writing task at hand. It might look pretty messy, and later you’ll need to delete the extraneous text. If successful, however, you’ve added words to your draft, and that is what’s important.</p>
<p>In practice, it might look something like this:</p>
<p><em>Ugh, ok, it’s 7:30 in the morning and I’m tired but I really need to finish this writing blog. I think I’m supposed to be writing about the freewriting method, which is a method that I advocate for a lot. There’s something helpful about being able to type without worrying about what goes on the page. Anyway, so how it works is that you just sit down and start typing, and typing, and typing to see what comes out. Eventually, you can get your brain warmed up and focused on the writing task at hand.</em></p>
<p>Granted, freewriting about the freewriting method is a bit… unusual, but hopefully you’ve gotten the point.</p>
<p>I think I’ve recommended the freewriting method to nearly everyone who has told me that they need to write something, but they don’t know <em>what</em> to write. The beautiful part about freewriting is that it truely, does not matter what goes on the page, especially in the beginning. And even after you’ve warmed up to the topic, you can <em>continue</em> to write in a stream of consciousness.</p>
<blockquote>
<p>Freewriting gives you the freedom to write whatever you want about your topic, in whatever order or phrasing makes sense to you.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>I can almost guarantee that if you’ve done your literature review and are at the point to generate a first draft, the freewriting method can get <em>at least</em> 70 to 80% of your content on the page. Again, yes, it will be messy writing and you’ll need to clean it up, maybe reorganize, rephrase, and refine to fit the flow of the outline. But the essential information will be there <em>for</em> you to revise, which was the initial goal.</p>
<p>To recap:</p>
<blockquote>
<p>Freewriting is a warm-up method that can also be applied to the drafting process.</p>
</blockquote>
<hr>
<p><strong>The <a href="https://alliancescc.github.io/post/draft_methods_intro/">introduction and full list</a> of methods for writing the first manuscript draft.</strong></p>

item.title: The 'Method' Method for Scientific Writing
item.description:
This writing method, the method, is better described as a writing ritual. Whether or not your brain has been adequately warmed up with a writing warm up and is ready to transition to writing, it always helps to have an external, perhaps physical, cue that it is time to write.

The exact ritual will, of course, vary from person to person. It can also vary according to the type of writing task as the mental state and process for writing a letter of recommendation or grant is necessarily different from that of drafting a manuscript.

My preference is to make a hot cup of coffee or tea before I sit down to write. The process of making the drink, along with the soothing comfort of holding a hot mug, help me to relax and shift my focus to writing. Other rituals can be a bit more… extreme, like the famous authors who reportedly sleep next to their manuscript, or hang upside down in anti-gravity boots.

If you don’t already have a pre-writing ritual or habit, create one. Choose your ritual, whether it’s changing your sweater, eating a special snack, or putting on headphones, then make sure you repeat it every time that you start to write. You may not notice much at first, but as you build the habit, you will begin responding more and more quickly to your chosen cue.

This post from the Literary Hub has another perspective on using the Method to write your first draft.

The introduction and full list of methods for writing the first manuscript draft.

item.title: Why Scientific Writing Warm Ups (and Exercise) are Essential
item.description:
